transcription.text: [ Music ]
If you're in the wrong room, this room is talking
about testing the merge with parallel universes.
My name is David Serle and I'm the head of a mirror
for a small startup that's been working
with the Ethereum Foundation for just over a year now.
Who likes bugs?
Okay, well I've brought some bugs along with me today,
so you're going to have to be, who would like a bug?
Because I've got some bugs that I actually would like
to give to various members of the audience.
Anybody?
You'd like one?
Okay, here we go.
Just have to, are you going to catch in?
Little bugs.
We've been spending the last year kind of really
stress testing, right, bug?
So you see, this is why you should set it at the front.
I've got three more to go.
There we go, see?
[ Laughter ]
So the talks about testing Ethereum
and it's basically looking at using a pretty sophisticated
and unique testing methodology which is based
from a company called Antithysys, which I belong to.
The company is involved in using deterministic
simulation techniques to allow us to basically explore
a whole host of iterations of complex distributed technology
that's running in a simulated environment.
So let me just get my little clicker.
I brought a few stars along to the show.
Obviously, I just explained who I am.
Little did you know that Dr. Strange and Shao
are also going to participate in this presentation.
I've got about 25 years' worth of experience
just in the tech industry.
For the last two in a bit years now,
I've been working for this business,
Synthesisys, and they've basically made me into somebody
that there's a bug hunter by by trade.
I never thought testing could be fun,
but there's nothing like hitting a segfault
and actually getting a real kick out of it.
And that's what I do on a day-to-day basis.
This is my house in the UK.
You can tell from my accent.
And as you can see, I've mostly got a few GPUs
I've got to sell.
So if you're interested, please let me know.
No joke.
But the day of the merge came round
and we'd been doing a lot of work with all the various clients,
all that hard, arduous testing,
making sure that we call every last bug.
What was going to happen?
Was it really going to be smooth sailing?
I think we saw this morning, which obviously is great news.
But I was wondering if we were going to see this.
I have to press the play on the video.
There is sound as well, but I couldn't
believe this when I saw this, but this is real.
[LAUGHTER]
I've got to put it in the shoe.
[GUNSHOT]
[GUNSHOT]
Yeah, it's pretty bad, eh?
Not my fault garden.
You don't really get it.
So testing is really important.
And this is where we talk about it,
but the merge was a significant event.
That's why we had so much celebration
across the world about what was really going on
when the merge took place.
So congratulations to anybody that was involved in the merge,
phenomenal job.
And I think we can hold our heads up high there.
So I say testing is hard, and you only
got to use QOR to basically ask the question,
what makes software testing difficult?
It's a bit of a high level question.
Apologies for that.
But these two really kind of struck me here.
The first one, this is basically fundamentally--
this is an impossible requirement,
because absence of evidence is not the evidence of absence.
And so often we run these simulations
in parallel universes hitting a whole host of code.
And it's clear.
And you're like, well, is that good?
Who knows?
We can only really understand how much coverage we've got.
And it may be good, maybe bad.
Who knows?
So that's a phenomenal kind of requirement.
The second one is then about understanding--
like testers have to think about all those possible scenarios
where issues may arise and ensure that they are handled
by the code.
And that's just not--
it's just like how do you approach that
with a distributed architecture like we have with Ethereum?
We've got a whole host of different clients
using different architectures.
We've got the execution layer.
We've got the consensus layer.
It's just-- it's amazing to see it actually working.
But the complexity of that is just phenomenal.
If we then look at kind of what Ethereum has done
to approach this task-- and this is not
looking specific antithesis--
we are a part of the equation.
And I think very much of a complementary
is that Ethereum is using unit testing test nets.
We've got a host of shadow forks and test net
mergies that occurred.
Some technologies that have been used
called Hive and Catosis that do similar features
to the equation.
We then have antithesis that is then
doing this deterministic piece, which
allows us to really get into the detail of all
the different iterations that are possible.
And then we have a host of different fuzzing technologies
that Ethereum are using to really try and isolate
and kind of hammer areas that are of concern.
So throughout the entire year, a huge amount of testing
has been done.
And on top of that, they've also used static analysis
to help with doing code audits and making sure
that we catch things before the merge was to take place.
I'll step back a little bit in terms
of the testing is hard statement.
It is a phenomenal kind of obstacle
to try and get over.
Like how do we find every iteration?
And how do we find those hard to reach bugs that may not
be common ground, but if they do occur,
will be catastrophic.
And so if we just look at the right hand side,
this is a representation of a distribution network.
So on the right, we're going to call this node.
We're going to call this node using Lighthouse and Geth.
So Lighthouse and Geth are running on this node.
They're running on an operating system, leveraging
CPU, the file system.
We've got different processes happening.
And then inside those processes, we've
got different threads being used as well.
So just in its own node, there's a lot of complexity
about what's going on.
And we can test the node.
We can test maybe a combination of Lighthouse and Geth
working together, making sure that we're pushing
the boundaries.
But if we then think about how we then have a network
and we have a whole host of different nodes running together
and may have other underlying pieces,
like databases and other pieces, kind of actually
on top of that.
The complexity of all those different communication
channels operating just means the search space for hidden away
little gems--
I call them gems, but they're bugs basically.
They can hide away for a long time.
And you may never find that search.
When you're looking at testing, you
may never find that particular condition where
the network is slow and there's a bit of thread
pausing going on in a certain node.
And the number of things that have to happen
could have a bug manifest.
And so this is where we step in because we then
have the complete picture.
And this is what we build inside our simulation.
We have the ability to run the entire collection
of consensus clients and execution
clients in a simulation, run it, and understand exactly
every way in which we can actually see outcomes.
That's pretty intense.
How do you do that?
And fundamentally, how do you do that in a deterministic fashion?
If we find a certain situation where lighthouse crashes,
well, can we represent that again?
Can we replay it?
Can we-- it's the first thing you do, right?
Can we reproduce it?
And often bugs are not reproducible.
They often-- they might try something different.
They might move around.
What-- like, how do we debug this?
And this is, again, where we step in.
So what do we do?
We leveraged the ability to all to generate networks
inside the simulation environment
and stand up all the containers that were necessary
to bring up Ethereum.
We then were able to then use network faults and other types
of faults to just inject chaos into that running environment.
Obviously, it's great to see the software handle that.
It's designed to handle these types of things.
So under duress, we see things going wrong.
And we basically use fuzzing technology
to basically hit the entire system,
not just individual pieces of software,
but the entire system is fuzzed.
And that allows us to basically kind of deterministically
replay the complete orchestration of a situation,
not just one particular application.
But we know that in this combination,
different clients, under these network conditions,
something goes wrong.
And so we use strategies inside the system
to allow us to seek rare events.
And so when I start looking at the numbers
of what we've been doing over the last year,
we hit a huge amount of code edges, a huge amount.
And so how do we find and allow ourselves
to seek out those edge cases that, if they do happen,
again, can be pretty catastrophic.
But get to them and uncover them
to help the client teams debug and fix.
So we have the ability to have all this wrapped up
in a tool set that is available to ourselves.
And we share it to the rest of the client teams and the F.
And that's been really, really useful.
I think if we look at it, we have the individual testing
going on, which is fantastic.
We continue to promote that and say, keep going with that.
We have the test nets and shadow forks.
Again, I think we can all say that they've
been tremendously successful and useful.
And then we have our parallel universes.
We have the ability to run not just one simulation,
but we're running simulations literally every day
that are generating and exploring the various search
spaces that exist across any number of different branches
inside the repositories.
So what does this mean for us?
Well, there's a little help from Dr. Strange here.
Hopefully you've seen it because it's not playing.
Here we go.
Strange.
You all right?
This is what I look like when I'm doing the work.

[GRUNTING]
You're back, Jo.
Hey, what was that?
Looking forward in time to view alternate futures,
to see all the possible outcomes of the coming conflict.
How many did you see?
How many do we win?
One.
So for us, winning is finding these edge cases, right?
You know, winning isn't like, oh, all test past.
Yeah.

of piece combinations and iterations
where we've covered 14 million different scenarios.

We can actually hold a hat on.

And we think that kind of represents

it will last 13 hours.

Pretty insane.

there's a lot going on.
So we see ourselves as a complementary piece.
We've been looking at this as a great example of a project
where we can basically work alongside all the other pieces
that the EFR are kind of using and different client teams are using.
So we're just another layer in the growing list
of strategies being used.
And I think that's sort of testament to the approach
that EFR have used to really hold onto this resilience,
making sure that we take advantage of every way
we can make sure that nothing untoward happens in the future.
More and more upgrades coming, I'm sure.
So we've only got 4844 around the corner.
I'll say around the corner, we'll see.

of making sure that we're involved every step of the way.
So this is a very simple sort of illustration
of what we've been doing.
We've been building all of the clients,
getting them in place and actually establishing Genesis.
So we actually have been using this at Genesis Block
and then moving it forward towards the merge in our world.
We would have the merge kind of positioned.
We obviously start fault injection.
We establish a chain, and then we start fault injection
to get to a point where we've got a whole host of different faults.
You can see them here labeled below.
So anything from partitioning, that's a great one,
obviously, to encourage forking of the chains.
We've then also got delays happening, drops of packets,
the nodes themselves.
We can stop.
We put this thing through its faces.
We stop things, we pour things, we kill things,
we bring them back up.
I suppose in some respects it's quite realistic.
Things do get rebooted and validators come back up again.
We have all that happening inside the simulation.
And then from that we then have any number of threads being paused,
released.
It's busy.
Every type of this sort of configuration of faults
that we put into a simulation is again completely deterministic.
So if we know that this ended up with a segfault,
we know we can literally put exactly the same into the environment,
it's basically creating a pure function of the entire system,
and we know we can get the exact same output,
which I think is a tremendous piece of technology which we have under the hood.
What are the numbers like?
Well, in one year we've conducted 31 years' worth of 24/7 nonstop testing.
That has processed and explored over 50 million edges of code.
Out of that, and you can see there, out of that we've got 45 violated errors,
some of which we're pated for, but 33 of them were logged bugs.
They were pretty catastrophic.
Things that really would bring either an actual node down,
so panics, segfaults, we'd have nil pointer exceptions,
we'd have, there's one now I'm going to bring up in a minute with a little example,
but things that you don't want to have like living in your code base.
And I think that's, we would forward those through to different client teams,
and they've been able to eradicate them, and obviously through the successful merge.
It's been great to see our efforts put to the test.
